intro: Brassica densiflora, commonly known as the denseflower mustard, is an annual flowering plant belonging to the Brassicaceae family. It is characterized by its dense clusters of small, yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and has alternate, lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy texture. Native to regions of Europe and western Asia, it thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in fields, roadsides, and waste areas. Its seeds are small and can remain viable in the soil for several years, contributing to its persistence in various habitats.
